questions.question: Q1: Your mentee shared an issue and you offered some suggestions but the mentee criticizes your suggestions, calling them stupid and impractical. What do you do?
options: 1. Reprimand the mentee to maintain your respect and authority.
2. Use humor to communicate with your mentees by laughing off the comment and responding in a manner similar to how the mentee spoke.
3. Ask the mentee why they found the suggestions stupid and impractical and then revise your suggestions or explain yourself better.
4. Accept the mentee’s harsh words as constructive criticism and communicate with them more consciously moving forward.
5. Ignore the comments and keep the atmosphere positive. Steer the conversation in another direction.
6. Clearly and calmly explain to the mentee why your suggestions are do-able.

questions.question: Q2: Your mentee shares that they have not left their room in days, do not feel like eating and haven’t been able to sleep. What do you do?
options: 1. Invite your mentee out for a fun evening, bond with them, and try to understand what is bothering them.
2. Speak to the mentee and let them know that you’re there for them and can be contacted anytime for any support.
3. Tell them that everyone gets depressed sometimes and they need to tough it out and emerge strong.
4. Try reasoning with them about their thoughts and emotions to get them back on track.
5. Suggest them to visit the Well-being Cell or SMP Faculty for the guidance and support since this isn’t your expertise and you may not be able to properly support them.
6. Make them aware of their academic and other responsibilities and work that is coming up so they can assess their priorities.

questions.question: Q3: Your mentee wanted to meet you but when you met they were sitting quietly. What do you do?
options: 1. Ask them why they wanted to meet and if they wanted to discuss something in particular.
2. Sit with them in silence until they feel comfortable enough to start talking.
3. Let them know about the other commitments you have coming up so they start talking.
4. Start talking about a common topic till they get comfortable enough to share with you.
5. Direct questions to them about your meeting and your life till you find out what the matter is.
6. Call other mentees so that the mentee can get comfortable by having their batchmates around and speak openly.

questions.question: Q4: You confront your mentee about their silence and they get uncomfortable and defensive. How do you aid the situation?
options: 1. Apologize to your mentee for upsetting them and let them know it won’t happen again.
2. Ask them if they are feeling uncomfortable to confirm before apologizing or taking any other action.
3. Wind up the meeting quickly to put an end to the awkward situation for both parties.
4. Deviate the conversation to another topic and not bring up the reason for meeting again.
5. You start with neutral conversation with them and then push them to find out more about the issues they may be facing.
6. Tell them you are just concerned for them and want to discuss with them and for that you expect them to open up.

questions.question: Q5: Your mentee does not seem to be making any friends in their batch and prefers finding you and spending all their time with you. How would you set a boundary if you don’t feel comfortable with this?
options: 1. Call a meeting with all mentees and try to help them to start making friends through that group interaction.
2. Communicate frankly and honestly that you need space and you don’t like their current behavior.
3. Give them the cold shoulder for a little time till the pattern breaks.
4. Let things be as they are because they are probably temporary and you do not wish to hurt someone new to college.
5. Let them know that you really appreciate their company but you’re feeling overwhelmed and offer an alternative like a regular meeting.
6. Ask your mentee to make friends with their batchmates or they won’t be able to grow.

questions.question: Q6: Why do you want to be IIITD Student Mentor?
options: 1. I have maintained a good academic and extracurricular record so I think I’d have a lot to offer to the program.
2. I am keen to pass on the college culture to the new students.
3. I am inspired by my mentor who helped me adapt to college and learn effectively.
4. I’m looking for personal growth and development and to add some leadership experience to my resume.
5. I have had a vast variety of experiences in college and I believe I can really help someone new adapt well.
6. I’m empathetic and easy to talk to so I’d help juniors assimilate with ease.
